speakers.bio: Sandi Metz, author of Practical Object-Oriented Design in Ruby and 99 Bottles of OOP, believes in simple code and straightforward explanations. She prefers working software, practical solutions and lengthy bicycle trips (not necessarily in that order) and writes, consults, and teaches about object-oriented design.
speakers.name: Sandi Metz
speakers.title: Programmer / Author / Teacher

speakers.bio: Guillaume Marty has been working on the web for 77% of its lifespan. In the last few years he shifted his focus from code to humans. He's passionate about contributing to a healthy, inclusive industry, and the intersection between communities and technology. He was formerly working at Mozilla, and currently at Twitter.
speakers.name: Guillaume Marty
speakers.title: Web lover / JavaScript activist / HTML5 enthusiast

speakers.bio: I combine my 13 years of professional software engineering experience with a passion for leadership and communication skills. My main focus is on how we can be better technical leaders and developers by focusing on learning the skills most of us ignore - communication and leadership skills. Originally from the UK but now based in Australia, I have consulted, performed workshops and developed software for clients across the UK, Australia, New Zealand and the United States. Technology in all its forms is part of my makeup and so I code, speak, write, teach, make, game and listen to all things geek
speakers.name: Andrew Murphy

speakers.bio: Milecia McGregor is a software engineer lost somewhere in the Midwest. She has mostly worked with .NET, Angular, and Azure to build web apps, but she also has a master’s degree in mechanical and aerospace engineering and has published research in machine learning and robotics. In her free time, she spends time with her husband and dogs while learning to play the ukulele and learning Japanese.
speakers.name: Milecia McGregor
speakers.title: Software Engineer

speakers.bio: I’m currently an engineer at Guru, as well as a mentor/instructor for an online code school called Thinkful. I’m also a co-organizer for the VueJS Philly and GitLab Philly meetup groups. I run my own YouTube channel focused on helping break down programming/web dev concepts into simple terms (or at least I try to). I’ll sometimes mess around making music, or exploring new coffee shops (trying to find the best coffee in Philadelphia).
speakers.name: Ryan Heupler
speakers.title: Mentor & Instructor

speakers.bio: Chris has worked at Comcast since 2007 – currently as a Distinguished Engineer. He enjoys building/motivating teams and ramping up new projects using the latest patterns and web primitives. Besides coding in Javascript, he loves spending time with his family and helping out in the community.
speakers.name: Chris Lorenzo
speakers.title: Distinguished Engineer

speakers.bio: Stacey resides in Fort Wayne, Indiana, and has over 20 years of Law Enforcement (LEO) and teaching experience. Law Enforcement experience: Homicide Detective • Gang Unit Specialist Detective • Hostage Negotiator • Crisis Intervention Team (CIT) Officer •S chool Resources Officer (SRO) • Five years as a Special Agent with the DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND (DHS). Stacey is currently working as a Detective with the Fort Wayne (Indiana) Police Dept., Gang, and Violent Crimes Unit. Teaching experience: Stacey is an Adjunct Professor: • Business Psychology • Psychology •Criminal Profiling •Criminal Behavior •Computer Psychology •Social Media Psychology •Sociology (Group Dynamics). Education: • Bachelor of Science degree; Criminology (Ball State University, 1994). • Master’s degree; Forensic Psychology (Walden University, 2012). • Currently, a Ph.D. Candidate (Forensic Psychology), at Walden University Affiliations/Memberships: • American Psychology Association (APA) •CIT International member #3036 •Golden Key International Honor Society • National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) • Omega Psi Phi Fraternity Inc. • Psi Chi International Honor Society (Psychology) • Society for Police and Criminal Psychology
speakers.name: Stacey Jenkins, M. Psych
speakers.title: Ph.D. candidate, International KeynoteSpeaker, BehavioralProfiler, MotivationalSpeaker, TeamBuilder, GroupDynamics.

speakers.bio: A third-generation Brazilian raised in the US, Gabi spent her youth immersed in MS-DOS, server rooms, and Geocities Mariah Carey fan page HTML. She transitioned to a development career in 2016 after spending 7 years as a systems administrator and is active in her local tech community. Namely, she’s the Mentor Director for Coding & Cocktails, a Kansas City Women in Technology program, which teaches monthly coding sessions to help women break into the industry. Amongst her other interests are included ashtanga yoga, learning languages, and curating stellar playlists.
speakers.name: Gabi Dombrowski
speakers.title: freelance web developer and no-ego doer

speakers.bio: Peter is an adventurous and passionate CodeSmith at Ordina Netherlands. He likes to travel around the world with his bike. Always seeking for the unexpected and unknown. For his job he tries out the latest techniques and frameworks. He loves to share his experience by speaking at conferences over the World and writing for the Dutch Java magazine and DZone. He believes that you as the front-end developer are the spider in the web to bring the user, the team and the product together.
speakers.name: Peter Eijgermans
speakers.title: CodeSmith

speakers.bio: Chris is a Staff Software Engineer at LinkedIn, based in New York City working on native video. He is an editor and contributor for both The Ember Times and the LinkedIn Engineering Blog.
speakers.name: Chris Ng
speakers.title: Staff Software Engineer

speakers.bio: Co-Founder of Techqueria untermensch Award-losing web developer all opinions expressed are plagiarized Too old for 30 under 30 been to UC Berkeley
speakers.name: David Silva
speakers.title: Co-Founder of Techqueria

speakers.bio:
I’m Kenigbolo Meya Stephen, Full Stack Software Engineer working as the Frontend Engineering Team Lead at BCaster OY. Formerly Arch Conveyer/Community Manage of CodeAfrique(now Reload), a not-for-profit weekend intensive software engineering bootcamp for underrepresented groups in IT based out of Estonia.'
'During my free time I sometimes volunteer as an open source developer for ADSBx, play golf and coach football (soccer as Americans call it). I also have a nick for writing tiny javascript modules on npm to help a few developers out there so they need not rewrite same utilities that we all might need (usually it’s the case that we’re only a handful needing those so there’s really nothing too worry much about).
speakers.name: Kenigbolo Meya Stephen
speakers.title: Frontend Engineering Team Lead

speakers.bio: James Simpson has spent the greater part of his life pushing the web forward by challenging what is possible in a browser. As founder of GoldFire Studios, he has focussed on real-time gaming, high scalability/performance and some of the largest HTML5 canvas games ever built. He is also passionate about open-source as the author of many projects, including the popular howler.js audio library.
speakers.name: James Simpson
speakers.title: Founder

speakers.bio: A software engineer at Josh Software, Works in JavaScript, Ruby, Golang.
speakers.name: Anusha Bhat
speakers.title: Software Engineer

speakers.bio:
Alfredo is a Director of Engineering at Hearst working with technical and non-technical teams to develop tools that abstract best practices and performance enhancements into measurable business goals.

His current interests include creating highly performant and flexible web applications that enable developers to be productive.

Prior to Hearst, Alfredo worked for an ad platform writing low-level JavaScript that catered to strict browser support requirements. Outside of the web, Alfredo is a musician, film enthusiast, and comedy fan.
speakers.name: Alfredo Lopez
speakers.title: Director of Engineering

speakers.bio: Robin is a UI engineer at Taulia, where she focuses on front end development in React. She is passionate about building stunning user interfaces and intuitive user experiences. She successfully transitioned from teaching ESL to kindergarteners in Shanghai to wrangling code and hasn’t looked back since.
speakers.name: Robin Dykema
speakers.title: UI Engineer

speakers.bio: I’m 28 years old from rural VA. I earned a BS in Economics in 2012, and after working at an education analytics startup after college, taught myself development. I started with frontend development but now happily work up and down the stack. I moved to Philadelphia three years ago to pursue a career in technology. I’ve worked at Comcast the past two years. I currently live in South Philly with my friendly cat, Rupert.
speakers.name: Jeffrey Smith
speakers.title: Design Technologist

speakers.bio: Liz Krane is a developer advocate at Sentry and founder of Learn Teach Code, an organization that empowers aspiring developers to lead their own local events to create stronger, more diverse tech communities. She loves finding new ways to combine code with other disciplines like art and music, sharing everything she learns while she tries to learn everything!
speakers.name: Liz Krane
speakers.title: Software Developer

speakers.bio: Ron Dagdag is a Senior Software Engineer with 20 years of experience working on a number of business applications using a diverse set of frameworks and languages. He currently support developers at Crestron Electronics with their IoT, Cloud and Voice AI Assistant development. On the side, Ron Dagdag is an active participant in the community as a Microsoft MVP, speaker, maker and blogger. Ron enjoys building projects with his 2 kids and he is passionate about Augmented Intelligence, studying the convergence of Augmented Reality, Machine Learning and Internet of Things.
speakers.name: Ron Lyle Dagdag
speakers.title: Senior Software Engineer

speakers.bio: Colleen is a free-spirited techie with a passion for Global Engineering. She’s a life-long learner with a passion for connecting with others. She loves Hackathons, Dogs, Coffee, and the Circus. Her passion projects include an online resource platform for LGBT+ individuals living in countries where Homosexuality is illegal, and a Solar Electric Stove startup called Sol Flame. She currently works at the Ifakara Health Institute in Bagamoyo, Tanzania, building technology tools for Malaria Researchers.
speakers.name: Colleen Dunlap
speakers.title: Software Developer

speakers.bio: Fen Slattery is the Accessibility Lead at Clique Studios, where they build beautiful things and work towards a more inclusive digital world. As a web engineer, Fen seamlessly translates the needs of users into digital experiences that minimize barriers to access. As part of their advocacy work, they have spoken across the US to audiences of all skill levels, been featured on many panels about inclusion in the tech industry, and have spread their passion for accessibility in mentorship of web professionals.
speakers.name: Fen Slattery
speakers.title: Lead Accessibility Engineer

speakers.bio: Front-end software engineer for Guru. Esports addict with an affliction for playing competitive games with 0 skills. Bootcamp graduate and organizer of Reactadelphia.
speakers.name: Domitrius Clark
speakers.title: Front-end Software Engineer

speakers.bio:
I am a UX Developer at Alley, where I help build headless digital experiences for publishers and nonprofit institutions, including Fortune and Colorado Public Radio. I was a Code for Philly Open Source Mentorship Program fellow and co-created the Interactive Mechanics Mentorship Program for Diversity and Inclusion in Tech.'
'I came to tech later in life, after a 12-year career as a fundraiser for some of Philadelphia’s most prestigious arts organizations. I wrote my first line of code at age 35 and built my first WordPress theme at 37. Outside of tech, I enjoy reading, cooking, and watching classic films.
speakers.name: Christina Deemer
speakers.title: UX Developer

speakers.bio: Viral Parmar is a Serial entrepreneur who runs ComExpo Cyber security company as well as Infinite Defense Foundation a non-profit organization in India. He is a Developer Advocate, Productivity Hacker, Open Source Strategist, Technical Evangelist, Community Liaison, International TechSpeaker, he is a Cyber Security researcher by profession and open source enthusiast working in a field of information security from last three years with the expertise in Cyber Crime Investigation, Public Key Infrastructure, Social Engineering, Web App Penetration Testing, Digital Forensics and Mobile Security. He found sever vulnerability in 150+ well known websites like Intel, your story and solved more than 100 cases of cyber-crime & online frauds. He is famous for his research Cyber Disorder and Who is spying on you. Trained 150,000+ people till now and aware them about privacy and security. Given Seminars and workshops in 150+ Organizations. He is Working with Mozilla foundation from last 2 years as Reps, Mentor in Mozilla Open Leadership Project, Coach(Privacy and Security) in MozSprint 2018, also working with L10N project on Pontoon, Rust and WebVR projects.
speakers.name: Viral Parmar
speakers.title: Cyber Security Researcher

speakers.bio:
Emily graduated from Stevens Institute of Technology in 2015 with her Bachelor’s and Master’s of Science in Computer Science, as well as a Bachelor’s of Arts in Visual Arts and Technology. After graduating, she entered the CORE Technology rotational program at Comcast NBCUniversal, where she worked on three different teams across the organization over the course of two years.'
'After completing the program, she joined Comcast’s Experience Design department as a UX Engineer, where she has been for the last two years. The prototypes Emily and her team develop help to guide production teams on building out final products, allow senior leaders to demo new ideas to executives, and for researchers to conduct user testing sessions will real life customers.'
'While her team specializing in build JavaScript web applications, Emily also has a passion for animation, is a Captain in the Air Force Reserve, and is an amateur aerial circus artist. One day, she might just run away and join the circus.
speakers.name: Emily Rautenberg
speakers.title: UX Engineer

speakers.bio: Diego Hernandez is a front-end developer at IBM and Software Engineering graduate student at DePaul University in Chicago. He is a trained filmmaker, turned self-taught developer and designer. As a creative person, Diego is always looking for ways to stretch his canvas—in this case, web browsers—to create unique web experiences that tell a story. When he’s not coding, you’ll probably find him attempting to rock climb or in the kitchen trying out a new recipe.
speakers.name: Diego Hernandez
speakers.title: Front-end developer

speakers.bio: Nathan Lilly is a UI Engineer at Comcast where he works on the Help and Support website. He has been developing websites since 1998 and recently received his Certified Web Professional in Accessibility certificate from the IAAP. He is an amateur dilettante who is constantly finding new various topics to love: in programming, creativity, the arts, history, philosophy, machine learning, cognitive science, superhero movies, and space westerns.
speakers.name: Nathan Lilly
speakers.title: UI Engineer

speakers.bio: George Mandis has been a freelance, full-stack web developer and consultant at SnapTortoise serving startups, small businesses, professional sports teams and entrepreneurs for over a decade. Recently he spent a year living as a digital nomad, inadvertently cheated while running a marathon in North Korea and ran a coding bootcamp out of Portland, Oregon. He writes frequently on technology, travel and other things at his website.
speakers.name: George Mandis
speakers.title: Full-stack web developer

sessions.description:
Research indicates that programmers are not entirely happy, and that much of this unhappiness arises from interactions with other people. Research also tells us that teams are capable of producing solutions that are more creative and of higher quality than those of single individuals. However, teams, by definition, consist of people--possibly the very ones who are causing our unhappiness.

This talk explores the science behind human persuasion, examines the roots of motivation, and reveals the single quality that all high-performing teams share. You’ll leave armed to persuade, primed to understand, and motivated to create teams that inspire everyone to do their best work.
sessions.title: You Are Insufficiently Persuasive

sessions.description: It’s something we all struggle with, admitting we don’t know something. But I’m here to show you the power of saying "I don’t know" to people. Saying "I don’t know" doesn’t have to be the end of a conversation, in fact it can be the start of an entirely new, exciting conversation with learning opportunities for all parties. We will talk through scenarios where we don’t feel comfortable saying it, ways we can feel comfortable saying it, and the good things that come from it. Outline/structure of the Session Why we don’t say I don’t know Why we should say it How to say I don’t know to clients How to say I don’t know as an expert How to say I don’t know as a leader A deep (and revealing) discussion on the underlying reasons why we feel afraid to say "I don’t know" to people.
sessions.title: The power of saying "I don't know"

sessions.description: The introduction of Hooks in React has become a very "buzz word" topic in the community, which, ultimately, has lead to some confusion. Some common questions I hear when talking to others are: What are they? How do you use them? Do they replace life-cycle methods and/or class components completely? We will go over all of these together. I'll start with a basic React app using a few stateful, class components using life-cycle methods, custom methods and API interaction. I will then convert the components over to functional ones while integrating several different hooks, without losing any functionality. Finally, we will look into some common "gotchas" that may be confusing for people starting out with hooks. You will come away from this talk with a good foundation for various primitive hooks in React, and you'll understand how they're used and how you can start to write your own custom hooks.
sessions.title: Refactoring a Class Component: A Gentle Introduction into React Hooks

sessions.description: The world of UI/UX is changing every month. It can be hard for developers to keep up with the newest trends and frameworks because of all the responsibilities they have. What if you could use machine learning to help you keep up with all of the changes? While it’s far from taking all of the programming jobs, machine learning can help developers make more user-friendly web applications. With the use of Brain.js, you can do text prediction, make small layout changes, check for malicious users, and more. In this talk, attendees will learn some background on machine learning and algorithms and see examples of where Brain.js can be used in real applications. We’ll cover business cases in web development where machine learning can help, how neural networks work, and how JavaScript can be used to train a model and make real-time updates for users. By the end of the talk, attendees should have a good understanding of basic machine learning concepts and an idea of how they could get started with Brain.js.
sessions.title: Using Machine Learning To Improve UI/UX

sessions.description: Faster, Better, Cheaper - the beating drum for software developers. Do you work in a large shop where teams are using Angular, Vue and React? With the multitude of frontend frameworks today, how do you share components between them? How do you build things once? Is it worth it? This talk will cover how Comcast front end teams are tackling these challenges. We’ll look at how we’re using Web Components to share code between sites and if they can be used to share components between frameworks. I’ll go over how we’re sharing data between codebases with Redux. Lastly we’ll talk about Shared Flows; pulling out complicated reusable logic into its own microsite. You’ll walk away learning from our experiences and being able to revisit how you build software to reuse code.
sessions.title: Strategies for Sharing Components ⚙

sessions.description: Which one is your favourite: ReactJS or Vue.js? Both ReactJS & Vue.js developers will get the same requirements for an application (Building Tesla’s Battery Range Calculator). Are you a Vue.js developer who wants to learn how to use ReactJS, or the other way around? Trust us, you can learn from each other, and that’s exactly what you will do on this session. We will give you a buggy application that you’ll have to fix before adding new features to it using either Vue.js or React. How fast will you go? Will you share your findings with other developers? You’re welcome to test this during our workshop. We have built the same application with ReactJS and Vue.js. We invite you to spend the session learning how to build such an app yourself with the help of our mentors. By the end of the session, you should be able to answer these questions: • What is Functional Reactive Programming? • How to use React and Vue.js? What are the main differences between Vue.js and React?
sessions.title: Building Tesla’s Battery Range Calculator with Vue.js or ReactJS

sessions.description: We often find ourselves in situations where we have to knowledge share and mentor others, but we often don’t take the time to learn how to be better mentors. How do we know if we’re doing ‘mentoring’ right, and what small things do we not know about that could be doing more harm than good? Through my work as over the past 3 years directing mentors at a monthly coding class, I’ve been able to compile effective methods through research and experience that will help all developers be better mentors, whether within an established mentor/mentee relationship or just in quick day-to-day teaching opportunities. By setting expectations, learning how to be more friendly and accessible, removing roadblocks, practicing self-care, developing empathy for mentees, and constantly iterating based on actionable feedback, we can all contribute to creating richer tech communities that thrive on constant improvement and collective growth.
sessions.title: The Mentor Playbook

sessions.description: This presentation will discuss how to cope with conversing with those who are from diverse backgrounds with ease and accomplish your daily connections with co-workers, who come from different backgrounds, with a common goal of comprehension. Necessities that makes you distinct, skills that make you stand out. The diversities that make us rare and unique if it’s your ethnic background, race, ethnic customs, religious beliefs, sex, sexuality, or form of individuality may also be a cause of contention. Discover how to bring out that, which is already within you and communicate, work with individuals who are diverse as well as, striking-up great conversation between one another. Also, this presentation will contribute to you your attendees with fostering a positive change and cultivate a more inviting place of work. This presentation will discuss the impacts of diversity collectively using identifying what variety can be combined with how it affects a business. The presentation will assist with explaining what it signifies being an inclusive place of work, offer comprehensive measures to assess best what degree one’s place of work fosters inclusion a and diversity. The workshop, through means of role-playing scenarios, present ways you can take to impact positive philosophies at your place of work. Individuals will take with them an increased perception of the implications of a tolerant, inclusive and diverse place of work. Individuals will take with them, along with personal skills, which one will utilize to develop into promoters of social change, that will build a more diverse workplace.
sessions.title: The Role of The Minority in The World of Technology

sessions.description: Everyone deploys code. For websites in particular, deploying code is often done behind the scenes without a user having to install an update since each new connection can be fulfilled with the latest version of the site. Having complete control of this process allows us to be creative in how fast or slow we deploy code in order to optimize for either maintainability of the code base, getting features out fast, or even both. While deployments seemingly look like a trivial final step, how we deploy code has far flung effects on how we write code. We will examine how each deployment strategy affects how developers produce code so that we can make an informed decision on the tradeoffs.
sessions.title: How Your Deployment Strategy Influences How People Code

sessions.description: Recently after becoming Frontend Engineering Team lead at BCaster I introduced an incremental migration shift from JQuery to VueJs. It sure did seem to be straightforward at first especially with proper test coverage, however 20% -25% into this migration we encountered a certain issues which meant re-evaluation of several architectural decisions that had been made in this regard. The goal of this talk is to give an in-depth analysis of the following - Highlight what we tried - Highlight where we failed and the lessons learned - Changes made related to the architecture - How we finally achieved 100% full migration of one of our most important projects into Vue JS
sessions.title: From Jquery to VueJS - Not Rocket Science

sessions.description: As web and native apps continue to converge, audio plays an ever-increasing role in elevating the user experience beyond simple static documents. However, even simple audio playback can get complicated when dealing with different browsers, devices and environments. In this talk, we’ll take a deep dive into using the howler.js audio library to enhance your web, desktop and mobile applications. Through a live coding demo, we’ll start with basic playback and work our way through audio sprites, live streaming, 3D spatial audio and more. Walk away with a better understanding of various use-cases for audio on the web and the simple tools you can use to enable them in your own projects.
sessions.title: Web Audio Made Easy with Howler.js

sessions.description:
We all know JavaScript is single threaded. We have written code till now based on that assumption. What if I tell you that Multi-threading is possible in JavaScript. You must be thinking I have gone nuts. “I am not crazy, my mother had me tested” :P

With the advent of PWAs, we are delegating a lot of processing to the client side. With JS being single-threaded, at times this results in jitter. Consider an example of client-side filtering on a very big list or image processing. Here, the main thread is blocked resulting in the end user being blocked.

What should we do now? Is it necessary to do all the computations in the main thread? Won’t it be great if we can perform computations in a worker thread and then notify the main thread about it?

Here comes background thread to the rescue. We can perform a heavy computation task in the background thread. Due to this, the main thread is unblocked and so is the user. Background and main thread can communicate asynchronously. I will be sharing my experience with background threads in JS.
sessions.title: Multi-threading in Javascript - Myth or Reality?

sessions.description:
Using Jovo Framework and Jovo CLI, developers can quickly develop voice-first applications for Alexa and Google Home within a single nodejs application. In this workshop, I show you how to quickly build, test, and deploy a voice app using Jovo, and leave with areas for further exploration.

Topics covered include: how to build a language model, how to use the Alexa and Actions on Google Simulator, how to create unit tests for voice applications, how to route through conversations, how to request user data, and how to extend the bot to other conversational platforms such as Facebook Messenger or Twilio SMS.
sessions.title: How to Build Cross Platform Voice Apps with the Jovo Framework

sessions.description:
Making room for performance optimizations is hard. It means different things to different people and is considered a goal to achieve and maintain. But a performance culture is not about being slow or fast, but the ability to make tradeoffs and tackle competing priorities, with a clear path back.

This is the story of establishing a performance culture by empowering non-technical team members to understand, own and act on their performance impact by following a path and checklist for each project.

By connecting the intention to goals and vision for a specific project, a performance path with best practices is created to guide the team through development, but more importantly, to understand the tradeoffs each decision has.

In this talk, we’ll cover the different paths to improve performance along with some JavaScript tips and tricks.
sessions.title: Think Fast, First: Empowering a Performance Culture

sessions.description:
What’s the difference between localization and internationalization? Should I store my translations statically, use my own API, or just use a third-party translation service? What sort of UX problems might I run into when translating my application? Do I have to revamp everything for RTL languages?

When I started working at my company, all our translations sat in static JSON files. Manually adding new translations was tedious and error-prone, every language loaded on every page, and new translations rarely made it in the same release as their accompanying feature work. This talk will discuss how we transitioned to using i18next to localize our app, the problems we had along the way and how we solved them, and tips for designing applications to minimize future localization issues.
sessions.title: Sacré bleu! The trials and tribulaciónes in localizing your application

sessions.description:
Have you ever wanted to build a web application but couldn’t due to poor internet connection? Have you ever wondered how applications are built for use in situations like Disaster Relief? If yes, then come learn about the extraordinary potential of PWAs and how you can build your own!

Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) are an up-and-coming technology that has piqued the interest of tech companies big and small. The talk will inform the audience about this new field, its potential, and how one can get started developing PWAs. This talk is both educational and imaginative, and will provide a launchpad for exploring a new way to use JavaScript.

First, this talk will be an introduction to Progressive Web Apps–what they are, their benefits (such as offering offline functionality, can be run as web page or native app, and increased performance speed), and tools to create them (my go-to tools are AngularJS and Firebase). I’ll also discuss how you can turn your existing Web App into a PWA in a matter of minutes. Secondly, this talk will cover how PWAs can be applied to fields such as Tropical Medicine, Poverty Alleviation, and Disaster Relief (this will include anecdotes from my experience building PWAs for researchers in Tanzania). Learn how you can apply your JS chops to create better web and mobile experiences in both ordinary and extraordinary circumstances!
sessions.title: The Unique Hows and Whys of Global Progressive Web Apps

sessions.description: The culture in tech is great: future-forward, evidence-based, data-driven. It's also not so great: it can feel exclusive and a little elitist. By the end of this talk, you will have applicable tools to make your team, your company and the whole industry healthier. How? By creating diverse and inclusive safe spaces.
sessions.title: Watch this (safe) space

sessions.description: How can we extract the most value from our front-end JavaScript errors, especially when users often don’t report them? We’ll learn about the evolution of the browser’s global error event handler, how to work around its limitations, and tools to make our JavaScript bugs a little less buggy.
sessions.title: Kicking Bugs and Logging Names: The Challenges of JavaScript Error Reporting

sessions.description: webUSB, webMIDI, webBluetooth, oh my web! In this session, we will explore what webUSB, webMIDI and webBluetooth API and how it safely expose device services to the web using JavaScript. This session is designed for web developers, makers who want to innovate and take their web apps to the next level.
sessions.title: Oh my web! Connecting to devices with your browser

sessions.description: Roughly 10% of people have a disability that impacts their use of the web, and lawsuits against inaccessible websites are becoming more common. How can we move beyond seeing accessibility as a legal requirement, and to championing inclusion for people with disabilities?
sessions.title: Digital Accessibility Beyond Legal Compliance

sessions.description: Headless architecture is a popular solution for projects that require cutting-edge user experiences and next-level performance, but the learning curve can be discouraging. In this talk, we’ll give participants tactics, tools, strategies, and confidence to make their first headless project a success.
sessions.title: Going Headless without Losing Your Head: Strategies for Making Your First Decoupled Web App a Success

sessions.description: ApolloClient and ApolloServer empower developers with control over the data they work with. This workshop will dig into using both along with Prisma to build a full stack application. We’ll tackle REST, Database setup, and authentication with ease using this amazing ecosystem!
sessions.title: Apollo: One Giant leap for Full Stack

sessions.description: By the end of the session the attendees will be able to Make a simple Demo of basic WebVR application and get into WebVR experiences, they Will also learn about WebVR concepts, A-Frame Framework, A-Frame scenes & apps in depth.
sessions.title: WebVR : Beyond Imagination

sessions.description: A Regular Expression is a sequence of characters used as a search pattern on a set of a text—but trying to read that sequence might look like something out of Stranger Things. This workshop will break down how regular expressions can be used in everyday programming to make manipulating data easier.
sessions.title: Demystifying Regular Expressions

sessions.description: Before you manually review your pages in an assistive technology device the International Association of Accessibility Professionals (IAAP) recommends that you use an automated testing tools to check your page. So you stop everything and review your page with a third-party website or browser extension… if you remember to. Why wait until you’re that far into development? Let’s build accessibility testing into your workflow, and prevent common errors from even being committed in the first place. I’ll give an overview of tools that exist, and share some code to help customize your own workflow. Familiarity with accessible development is not needed, but you should be familiar with HTML, JavaScript, Git, and NPM.
sessions.title: Building Accessibility Testing Into Your Workflow

sessions.description:
As web applications continue to evolve into complex systems, developers today are building more and more UIs with component-based frameworks like React and Vue. As a result, UI testing today is easier than it has ever been before. But where do you start? If you feel like it’s a guessing game, this is the talk for you!'
'In this talk, I will guide you with a practical approach to testing UI components with Jest and Storybook to improve your UI’s quality and solve your users’ needs.
sessions.title: Strengthening your blocks: A practical guide to UI component testing

sessions.description: Did you know there’s a widely-supported browser API that allows you to interface with lots of hardware, including custom controllers you can build yourself? Meet the WebMIDI API! Natively supported by Chrome (and soon Firefox!) we’ll experiment with talking to custom hardware through the browser.
sessions.title: JavaScript + MIDI + Microcontrollers Workshop
